Medienätverket BIRN har ansökt till Sida om stöd för sin verksamhet under perioden 2015-2019. BIRN består av ett nätverk av redaktörer, journalister och medieutbildare, vars mål är att utveckla en stark, professionell och oberoende media i sydöstra Europa. BIRN har redaktionell närvaro i nio länder i regionen. Formella nätverksmedlemmar är fristående NGOs i Albanien, BiH, Kosovo, Makedonien, Serbien och Rumänien samt en regional nätverkshub i Sarajevo. En kommersiell gren, BIRN Ltd, inrättades i Belgrad för att handha kommersiell verksamhet och bidra till finansiell hållbarhet.
BIRN är en av få oberoende grävande och granskande medieröster på Balkan och åtnjuter högt anseende. De producerar egna undersökningar, analyser och artiklar, varav stor del återpubliceras i andra medier. De arrangerar olika evenemang som debatter, seminarier, utbildningar, fellowships och sommarskolor för journalister och mediefolk i regionen. Tematiskt fokus är bl.a. övergångsrättvisa, krigsförbrytelser och rättegångsövervakning i samband med detta, korruption och missförhållanden i offentlig förvaltning och samhället i stort, samt tillgång till rättigheter.
BIRNs verksamhet är bred och har betydande genomslag. Under 2013 t.ex. producerade BIRN 10 000 artiklar och över 1000 undersökande artiklar/analyser, 191 TV-debatter och 61 radioprogram, deras websida hade 6 miljoner träffar och social media 260 000 följare. De har anmält över 400 ärenden angående informationsfrihet (FOI) och mottagit nio journalistpris, nationella och internationella.
BIRN har en lång rad givare som ger olika projektstöd. Sida bidrar med ett kärnstöd om max 35 msek under perioden januari 2015 till december 2019 för att genomföra den femåriga strategi som BIRN presenterat. Stödet ges via nätverkshuben, som också är avtalspart, men kärnstöd fördelas även till nätverksmedlemmar.

The media network BIRN (Balkan Investigative Reporting Network) has applied to Sida for core support for their activities during the period 2015-2019.
Distribution: No country allocations.
BIRN consists of a network of editors, journalists and media trainers, whose goal is to develop a strong, professional and independent media in South Eastern Europe. BIRN has editorial presence in nine countries in the region. Formal network members are independent NGOs in Albania, BiH, Kosovo, Macedonia, Serbia and Romania and a regional Network Hub in Sarajevo. A commercial branch, BIRN Ltd., was set up in Belgrade to generate income to sustain network operations. BIRN is one of rather few independent, investigative and critical media organizations in the Balkans and enjoy high esteem and credibility. Their operations are many and wide-spread and have a significant impact. They produce their own investigations, analyses and articles, which are largely re-published in other media. They arrange many events such as debates, seminars, training courses, fellowships and summer schools for journalists and media professionals in the region. Thematic focus include: transitional justice, war crimes and trial monitoring (“facing the past”), corruption and mismanagement in public administration and society at large, as well as access to rights.
In 2013, for example, produced BIRN 10,000 articles and more than 1,000 investigative articles / analyzes, 191 televised debates and 61 radio shows. Their website had 6 million hits and BIRN social media 260,000 followers. They have filed over 400 Freedom of Information law requests and received nine journalism awards, national and international, only in 2013.
BIRN has a long list of donors who give various project support. Sida contributes with core support of a maximum of SEK 35 million during the period January 2015 to December 2019 to implement BIRN’s five-year strategy. Agreement party is the Network Hub, who also sub-grant parts of the Sida core support to BIRN members.

description.narrative: Sida has been contributing with core support to BIRN to implement BIRN’s five-year strategy. Sida have contributed with a total of 45 MSEK during the period January 2015 to December 2020. Agreement party is the Network Hub, but parts of the Sida core support is sub-granted to BIRN members (BiH, Kosovo, Nmk, Serbia). BIRN Albania is however excluded as they have a bilateral agreement with the Emb of Sweden in Tirana. Apart from the western Balkan, there has also been activities in Moldova and Ukraine, covered with Sida funds. (The Ukraine “project” ended with the end of 2019, while in Moldova they commission texts on under-reported topics.) When Sida - BIRN first entered into cooperation, BIRN were a quite small organisation. A pre-grant review identified the need to increase organizational capacities and institutionalize systems, routines and resources. Sida notes that BIRN has developed substantially over the years and made good overall progress. BIRN present impressive results in an environment where media is becoming less independent and where many journalists are subject to threats and in some cases violence. Some results reported (2019): For example, on Outcome 1, People having increased access to accurate information, BIRN has during 2019 published 2,700 news pieces and 950 premium articles. Their media content have reached 3,126,000 people, and the website has had over 8 million views. BIRN texts were republished or quoted close to 30 thousand times in the region and beyond, in media outlets, reports of international institutions and academic studies, regionally and internationally. In 2019, BIRN Hub expended its Resonant Voices Initiative (RVI) that aims toempower a diverse group of civil society actors – activists, journalists, bloggers, educators, and other online (and offline) influencers – to strategically engage in online and offline communication campaigns, utilising technology, together with a deep understanding of their communities, to produce compelling content that effectively pushes back against polarising, inflammatory, and radicalising discourse. During 2019 the project Justice Report Ukraine was launched as part of BIRNs Transitional Justice Programme, in cooperation with the Ukrainian media outlet Hromadske. This project is financed through the Sida support. In 2019 BIRN also continued its work on raising the standards of journalism in the region and beyond by providing training in different forms. 120 journalists has been trained through its programmes. Outcome 2, people having increased influence on democratic processes Between January 2017 and June 2019, BIRN journalists submitted 854 officialrequests to access public documents in Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, North Macedonia, Montenegro, and Serbia, as part of BIRN report published by in 2019 that aims to showcase the level of open data. The report shows that while Freedom of Information laws in the region are among the most liberal in Europe on paper, implementation of these laws is well below the European standards. Implementation also varies between the Western Balkan countries themselves. The report describes that BiH is now the only country in the Balkans that does not even offer access to public records in electronic form. In some other countries, like Montenegro and Serbia, there has been a decline in implementation, as a result of legislative changes and political pressures. In 2019, FOI requests were sent on regular basis to public institutions asking for indictments, first-degree verdicts and final verdicts in war crimes cases. BIRN Albania has developed an interactive online database and mobile application with open data on more than 570 projects in all the 61 municipalities of the country, to increase the level of information on the central government investments to the local level. BIRN Albania has sent more than 150 FOI requests to more than 70 institutions during 2018 and 2019 to gather and publish more than 800 public contracts and 1000 photos related to these projects. In the reporting period BIRN transitional justice team closely cooperated with CSOs from the WB region that are dealing with transitional justice issues, mainly through reporting about their activities, mainly organisations representing victims in all countries in the region. BIRN Albania has organised three national workshops during 2019, with the aim to strengthen the collaboration between CSOs and journalists. around 60 journalists, experts and civil society representatives participated. Regarding Outcome 3 and the internal life of the network, the work on the financial and operational software has started and the contract with implementing partner has been signed. During 2019 BIRN finalised the remaining procedures and adopted the Network Rules and Regulations (an umbrella document integrating all rules as a main network guiding document, along with the Network Partnership Agreement).
